text: Pablo ecchi expected more from his
return to see without a Colton after 15
months of living in a drug treatment
center he had big plans to find a good
job and support his children and to
replace the house he had destroyed in a
drug-fueled rage but he was unable to
turn it all around and instead he turned
once again to an old companion a drug
called Paco I can smoke my dose and I
lived it I'm living now I'm going the
hallway with my drug and period and I
have to deal with those things I don't
want to deal with today now you
understand when we first met Pablo two
years ago he was in a drug abuse
treatment center and in the midst of
turning his life around but escaping
Paco's grip has proven to be a struggle
the drug made from the leftovers of
cocaine production and a host of
chemicals like kerosene and rat poison
is cheap and readily available it is
often made in people's kitchens and
whole families are involved in producing
and selling the drug in shanty towns
like see without occulta the drug is so
new and so insidious that doctors have
yet to find a treatment protocol to beat
the addiction
Pablo has been in and out of psychiatric
clinics and chemical dependency centers
since 2001 but so far nothing seems to
be helping his addiction I want to quit
now so I can dress better but not to
quit that doesn't cross my mind
Paco is a growing problem for more than
just Pablo the scourge has deepened
since the drug hit the streets of Buenos
Aires around 2003 and drug use experts
here estimates some 50,000 people have
become addicted this looks more like
Paco its yellowish police have been
conducting raids and arresting the
sellers of Paco because of the desperate
pleas of local activists activists like
Bill McCune iya Pablo's mother a Cunha
believes that besides police raids
authorities should focus on the root
causes of Paco spread through the shanty
towns the lack of jobs that pay a decent
wage the sense of hopelessness she
helped found mothers against Paco a
group dedicated to preventing young
people from falling prey to the drug it
is painful to watch her son descend into
drug addiction again and it's harsh ugly
painful to see them like that and so
they ought to using drugs they forget
and reality catches up and they begin to
die slowly and they know it they know
they're killing themselves for Pablo the
future is cloudy he struggles to find
the will to escape the cycle of
treatment centers and doctors and the
emptiness he feels in Ciudad oculta
how do you see the future what are your
hopes
see I don't know anything about the
future what is the future I don't
understand I don't for The New York
Times this is Alexa Barton wherever
you
